title: Electron Correlation Microscopy: In Situ 4D STEM for Fluctuating Systems
content: Electron correlation microscopy (ECM) is an experimental method for studying temporal fluctuations in materials with sub-nanometer spatial resolution [1]. It has been used to study fluctuations in supercooled liquids [2] and aging in glasses [3]. The equivalent synchrotron technique, x-ray photon correlation spectroscopy (XPCS) has been used to study a wider variety of problems, including colloids, polymers, and ferroelectric and ferromagnetic domain fluctuations. In principle, ECM could be applied to many of these areas as well.
